diagnoses.label: bilateral thalamic stroke
evidence_spans: MRI Brain revealed bilateral thalamic strokes

diagnoses.label: intraatrial septal aneurysm with right to left shunt
evidence_spans: Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed an intraatrial septal aneurysm with right to left shunt

diagnoses.label: supranuclear vertical gaze palsy OU
evidence_spans: Neuroophthalmologic evaluation revealed evidence of a supranuclear vertical gaze palsy OU

diagnoses.label: severe impairment of anterograde verbal and visual memory
evidence_spans: Neuropsychologic assessment 1/12-15/93 revealed severe impairment of anterograde verbal and visual memory, including acquisition and delayed recall and recognition

diagnoses.label: impaired verbal associative fluency
evidence_spans: Speech was effortful and hypophonic with very defective verbal associative fluency

diagnoses.label: impaired 2-D constructional praxis
evidence_spans: There was impairment of 2-D constructional praxis

medications.name: aspirin
evidence_spans: She continues to take ASA 325 mg qd
She was last seen on 5/2/95 and was speaking fluently and lucidly

patient_summary: This patient was admitted after experiencing sudden blindness, tongue numbness, and slurred speech. She was found to have bilateral thalamic strokes and an intraatrial septal aneurysm. She is currently taking aspirin and needs routine follow-up with a neurologist. She has some mild decreased vertical eye movements.
notes: The patient's symptoms were significantly improved upon arrival at UIHC. The cause of the initial symptoms is not fully elucidated, but the MRI findings suggest bilateral thalamic strokes. The patient's cognitive function is impaired, but there has been some improvement since the initial assessment. The patient is currently taking aspirin for secondary prevention of stroke. The patient's vision is mildly decreased, but she is able to see and communicate. The patient's symptoms are being monitored closely.
